are useful for the cutting and dissection of various tissues. Some of them have a unique design for cutting fine and delicate tissues. The sharp blade scissors are useful for cutting dense tissues.
Dissecting Scissors:
is the most precise tool for tissue dissection and, in comparison to scissors or blunt dissection, causes the least trauma to surrounding tissue.
Featuring smooth, sharp points and accurately formed heads, these sturdy, nickel-plated dissecting pins are useful for pinning loose flaps of skin and positioning limbs.

There are different styles of forceps to suit many applications where grasping or handling tissues and specimens is required, such as surgery, post mortem, veterinary and dental labs as well as dissection of tissue samples and also general lab use.

Dissecting Towel:

is a long-sleeved, buttoned protective garment made of cotton or polyester blends, worn in labs to shield clothing and skin from hazardous spills, commonly featuring pockets for tools and used to ensure safety and cleanliness in scientific, medical, and research settings.
Lab Coat:
is a shallow tray with a wax or silicone bottom that securely holds specimens with pins during dissection, providing stability and containing fluids for accurate examination.
Dissecting Pan:
Use dissecting pins to secure the fish to the dissecting pan. Use scissors to make the cuts through skin and muscle.
STEP 1:
After making the cuts, carefully lift off the flap of skin and muscle to expose the internal organs in the body cavity.
STEP 2:
Locate the cream colored liver in the front of the body cavity. Also locate the gall bladder between the lobes of the liver.
STEP 3:
Remove the gall bladder and liver to observe the short esophagus attached to the stomach. Label the stomach
STEP 4:
At the posterior end of the stomach are the coiled intestines.
STEP 5:
Find the small reddish brown spleen near the stomach
STEP 6:
Below the operculum, are the bony gill rakers.
STEP 7:
In front of the liver and behind the gill rakers is the pericardial cavity containing the heart. The heart of a fish only has 2 chambers ---an atrium and a ventricle.
STEP 8:
In the upper part of the body below the lateral line is the swim bladder. This sac has a thin wall and gives the fish buoyancy.
STEP 9:
Below the swim bladder are the gonads, testes or ovaries. In a female, these may be filled with eggs.
STEP 10:
Find the 2 long, dark kidneys in the posterior end of the Tilapia. These filter wastes from the blood.
STEP 11:
Wastes exit the body through the vent located on the ventral side of the Tilapia.
